thread.title: When the NYSE malfunctions, here’s what happens to Twitter
thread.title_full: When the NYSE malfunctions, here’s what happens to Twitter - MarketWatch

author: By     Sally French
title: When the NYSE malfunctions, here’s what happens to Twitter
text:
The New York Stock Exchange on Wednesday temporarily suspended trading in all symbols.
With the exchange frozen for over an hour and confusion over when trading will resume, the halt is unprecedented.
Twitter activity massively spiked following the halt in trading, as traders, analysts, and members of the media let loose to make jokes, share information and postulate theories for what caused the halt.
The Nasdaq takes home the award for most shade thrown.
Nasdaq systems are operating normally and are trading all symbols including Tape A (NYSE) securities.
— Nasdaq (@NASDAQ) July 8, 2015 I got some video from the Bloomberg newsroom pic.twitter.com/xCL4Qyw4d5
— Rusty Foster (@rustyk5) July 8, 2015 Nobody panic, all the Bitcoin exchanges are fine
— Christopher Mims (@mims) July 8, 2015 Have they tried turning the stock exchange off & turning it back on?
— Spencer Ackerman (@attackerman) July 8, 2015 Jokes aside, Twitter also became a source of information as market watchers rushed to keep up with goings-on.
Here is that spike in $VIX when @NYSE was forced to halt trade on its floors today @HalftimeReport pic.twitter.com/mUK7U7NGst
— Jon Najarian (@optionmonster) July 8, 2015 11:32:57 - trades from NYSE drop sharply, sputter a few minutes, then nothing. Each dot a NYSE trade pic.twitter.com/QmJl8Y2b91
— Eric Scott Hunsader (@nanexllc) July 8, 2015 NYSE historian John Gordon says he doesn't remember a complete outage lasting more than 3-4 minutes.
 @CNBC #NYSE
— Carl Quintanilla (@carlquintanilla) July 8, 2015 As this chart shows, the NYSE started out low at 9:30. At 10:45 things went down hill: pic.twitter.com/qLnk1TduDJ
— Eric Scott Hunsader (@nanexllc) July 8, 2015 Of course, here’s the good news:
First, @zerohedge , then @united , then @nyse and now @wsj . But @MarketWatch still up (fingers crossed)
— Steve Goldstein (@MKTWgoldstein) July 8, 2015 More from MarketWatch
